comments.body: How to configure this backend ?
It is not configurable - if you want the old behaviour back you need to take this code, make it available in your install and configure the auth backend for the webserver to use it.

Why we did a breaking change without option to configure this ? 
Not everyone is using TLS enabled LDAP.
Upgrade from 1.10.0 to 1.10.1 completely broke my Airflow instalation. 
And this should be bugfix release.
(Continuing the conversation on Jira now)

comments.body: The `_api` suffix is out of place, so please can we rename `gcp_api` to simply `gcp`?

I want to do it in a separate PR, because I do not think that everyone will agrees with this change. This PR is responsible only for reducing the number of packages in the case of azure and aws. In the next PR I will introduce your change and I personally support it, but I do not want to introduce any unrelated changes in this PR. If this change is accepted, it will immediately prepare another one, which will introduce the proposed change and will also update `UPDATING.md`.

Look at previous discusion: https://github.com/apache/airflow/pull/4524/files#r249197669

comments.body: @ashb I'm wondering what will happen if I have both env variables `AIRFLOW_HOME` and `AIRFLOW__CORE__AIRFLOW_HOME` , but set to different values?
To the code the second one is the same as setting it in the config file

Having re-read this: this is the very problem I ran in to that caused me to issue the PR. If the are set to different values then the webserver_config.py would be looked for in one, but other things from the other.

Specifically the problem I had was that webserver_config.py was written to one, but read from the other! So `airflow create_user` etc targeted an `sqlite://:memory:` DB!

comments.body:
typo?
both L50 and L51 are the same name now, I wonder could we keep loading-duration or loading_duration and last_runtime, but change from dag to dag_processing? Or anything I missed here...

These metrics were _almost_ identicaly.

**`loading-duration`**:
 https://github.com/apache/airflow/blob/23ec78a42403ce9df062cee6371cd28cc0834206/airflow/models/dagbag.py#L411-L413
https://github.com/apache/airflow/blob/23ec78a42403ce9df062cee6371cd28cc0834206/airflow/models/dagbag.py#L388-L393

So loading-duration is the time taken for the `process_file()` call.

**`last_runtime`**:

https://github.com/apache/airflow/blob/f497d1d5aad9d88d6c1cd1dfa28546e7a8c5cb5f/airflow/utils/dag_processing.py#L950-L953
https://github.com/apache/airflow/blob/f497d1d5aad9d88d6c1cd1dfa28546e7a8c5cb5f/airflow/utils/dag_processing.py#L1113-L1114

`last_runtime` was the time taken to by the subprocess that calls `process_file()`, so would always be strictly greater than last-duration.

Having two metrics that were almost but recorded slightly different things seemed more confusing than not to me.
I C

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +49,53 @@- `collect_dags` -- use `dag_processing.total_parse_time` instead
- `dag.loading-duration.<basename>` -- use `dag_processing.last_duration.<basename>` instead
- `dag_processing.last_runtime.<basename>` -- use `dag_processing.last_duration.<basename>` instead

comments.body: Can you describe the consequences for the end-user i.e. all jobs is started using Python 3 by default now?

I think it's good enough for now @mik-laj -> I think what we really need in UPDATING.md is to record all the changes, and before we release 2.0.0 we should prepare some more complete migration guide for the users.

This should include a tool that will mostly automate migrating DAGs and correcting the DAGs they have where needed and print warnings for all cases that need some manual review and corrections (with appropriate instructions). But I think those instructions should be part of that tool rather than UPDATING.md.
I will create an issue about it.
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-6390 created and proposed that in devlist.
